coredata.dc:title: Insect vector–plant virus interactions associated with non-circulative, semi-persistent transmission: current perspectives and future challenges
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Ng, James CK
Zhou, Jaclyn S
coredata.dc:description: The non-circulative, semi-persistent (NCSP) mode of insect vector-mediated plant virus transmission is shaped by biological, molecular and mechanical interactions that take place across a continuum of processes involved in virion acquisition, retention and inoculation. Our understanding of the interactive roles of virus, insect vector, and plant associated with NCSP transmission is still evolving. Mechanisms exist that determine where and how virion acquisition (from the plant) and retention (in the insect vector) are achieved, with both processes being mediated by strategies involving viral capsid proteins, in some cases aided by non-capsid proteins. By contrast, mechanisms underlying virion inoculation (to the plant) remain poorly understood. Here, we review the established paradigms as well as fresh perspectives on the mechanisms of NCSP transmission.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Retention in yet to be identified locations

ce:figure.ce:label: Figure 1

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Aphid and whitefly feeding behaviors associated with the transmission of NCSP viruses, and sites in the anterior alimentary canal of specific hemipteran vectors where the NCSP viruses that they transmit are retained. (a) Comparison of the phloem-seeking and phloem-feeding behaviors between aphid and whitefly. In this diagrammatic illustration, both insects are on the abaxial (under)side of the leaf. (Left) Oblique frontal view of an adult apterous aphid and (right) lateral view of an adult whitefly, revealing the stylet tracks (st) created during the intercellular movement of the maxillary stylets (ms) and the intracellular probing/sampling of cells in the epidermal and mesophyll layers (indicated by yellow stars) and/or the vascular bundle (indicated by dark blue stars) where the phloem (represented by purple colored cells) is located. Note the difference in the probing/sampling locations of the two insects. (b) Diagrammatic sagittal section through the head of a generic hemipteran insect vector (art work courtesy of Greg Walker), illustrating the ingestion (green arrows), salivation (blue arrows) and egestion (red arrows) pathways as well as the retention sites of known stylet-borne (blue box) and foregut-borne (translucent, blue-shaded region) viruses. As noted in the text, the ingested fluid is a mixture of sap and, presumably, saliva. Insect anatomical features relevant to the transmission of NCSP viruses are indicated. Insets b1 and b2: widefield fluorescence microscopy images of the whole-mounted maxillary stylets of aphid vector Acyrthosiphon pisum. The maxillary stylets were treated (b1) or not treated (b2) with proteinase K before being subjected to in vitro binding using the green fluorescent protein (GFP)-marked P2 protein (P2-GFP) of CaMV; only the stylets that did not receive proteinase K treatment (b2) contained GFP fluorescence in the acrostyle (as) located at the tip of the stylet bundle. Inset b3: confocal laser scanning microscopy image of the whole-mounted head (posterior view) of a whitefly vector (Bemisia tabaci New World species) that fed on LIYV and then sequentially on biotin-labeled anti-LIYV antibody and quantum dot (QD)605-labeled streptavidin, showing the presence of specific QD signals (see enlargement in inset b4) in the foregut. The positions of the eye, cibarium (cb) and maxillary stylets (ms) are indicated. (c) Transmission electron micrograph of an ultra-thin section through the head of a leafhopper (Graminella nigrifrons) that fed on MCDV, showing the presence of spherical virion-like particles (VLPs; V) associating with the cuticular intima (CI) of the pharynx, as well as in the lumen (L) of the pharynx. (d,e) Transmission electron micrographs of ultra-thin sections through the head of an aphid vector (Cavariella aegopodii) that fed on AYV (d) or the AYV/PYFV complex (e), showing the presence of spherical VLPs.

ce:figure.ce:source: (b1,b2) Reproduced from Ref. [23•• ], copyright (2007) National Academy of Sciences, USA; (b3) reproduced from Ref. [33]; (c) reproduced from Ref. [21] with permission; (d,e) reproduced from Ref. [22] with permission.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Hemipteran vectors of plant viruses with a non-circulative, semi-persistent mode of transmission.

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: a
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: One to three representative virus species of each genus, for which the major criteria for NCSP transmission - i.e. no evidence of virion circulation or multiplication in insect vectors, retention of virions in the maxillary stylets or foreguts of insect vectors (if known), retention periods of hours to days, and loss of transmission upon insect molting - have been evidently fulfilled (as reported in the literature), are shown. AYV, Anthriscus yellows virus; BYV, Beet yellows virus; BRNV, Black raspberry necrosis virus; CaMV, Cauliflower mosaic virus; CBSV, Cassava brown streak virus; CPMMV, Cowpea mild mottle virus; CTV, Citrus tristeza virus; CVYV, Cucumber vein yellowing virus; CYSDV, Cucurbit yellow stunting disorder virus; GLRaVs, Grapevine leafroll associated viruses; GVA, Grapevine virus A; GVB, Grapevine virus B; LCV, Lettuce chlorosis virus; LIYV, Lettuce infectious yellows virus; MCDV, Maize chlorotic dwarf virus; PFYV, Parsnip yellow fleck virus; RTBV, Rice tungro bacilliform virus; RTSV, Rice tungro spherical virus; RYNV, Rubus yellow net virus [52]; SqVYV, Squash vein yellowing virus; ToChV, Tomato chocolate virus; ToMarV, Tomato marchitez virus; ToTV, Tomato torrado virus.

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: b
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: Taxonomic classification as reported in Sanfacon et al [53].
c,d Except for GLRaV-2 and -7, which are in the genus Closterovirus and the genus Velarivirus [54], respectively.

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: e
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: CTV, BYV, MCDV and RYNV are phloem-restricted, but invasion of mesophyll cells have been noted [55–57]. RTBV has been found in the vascular bundle (phloem and xylem) of infected plants [58].

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: f
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: FG, foregut; A, acrostyle (located at the tip of the maxillary stylets); P, proboscis (houses the maxillary and mandibular stylets; the putative retention site as determined for ToTV).

ce:table-footnote.ce:label: g
ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: AYV and RTBV are transmissible independently or as AYV/PYFV and RTBV/RTSV complexes, respectively. PYFV and RTSV are non-transmissible without AYV and RTBV, respectively. H, helper; C, capsid (as determined for LIYV).

head.ce:title: Insect vector–plant virus interactions associated with non-circulative, semi-persistent transmission: current perspectives and future challenges

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology and Center for Disease Vector Research, University of California, Riverside, CA 92521, USA

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Plant Pathology and Microbiology and Center for Disease Vector Research, University of California

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The non-circulative, semi-persistent (NCSP) mode of insect vector-mediated plant virus transmission is shaped by biological, molecular and mechanical interactions that take place across a continuum of processes involved in virion acquisition, retention and inoculation. Our understanding of the interactive roles of virus, insect vector, and plant associated with NCSP transmission is still evolving. Mechanisms exist that determine where and how virion acquisition (from the plant) and retention (in the insect vector) are achieved, with both processes being mediated by strategies involving viral capsid proteins, in some cases aided by non-capsid proteins. By contrast, mechanisms underlying virion inoculation (to the plant) remain poorly understood. Here, we review the established paradigms as well as fresh perspectives on the mechanisms of NCSP transmission.

ce:sections.ce:para: This review comes from a themed issue on Virus–vector interactions
Edited by Anne E Simon and Scott C Weaver
For a complete overview see the Issue and the Editorial

ce:section.ce:para: ‘The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step’—an adage by Lao Tzu, underscores a symbolic, but fitting characteristic of disease transmission. For plant viruses, the first step in transmission begins with overcoming the spatial distance that exists among plants. This is achieved, in most cases, by vectors, the most common of which are insects from the order Hemiptera. This large order of insects includes plant-feeding vectors in the families Aphididae (aphids), Aleyrodidae (whiteflies), Cicadellidae (leafhoppers), Fulgoroidea (planthoppers), Psyllidae (psyllids), Pseudococcidae (mealybugs), Coccidae (soft scales), as well as other vector and non-vector families. Phytophagous hemipterans use their stylets to feed (by sucking) on sap that flows within the phloem sieve elements in the vascular system located several cell layers beneath the plant surface. En route to the phloem, stylets may also probe and sample the contents of cells that are located outside the phloem [1,2]. Consequently, viruses in locations accessed by the stylets can be acquired and, if all goes well, transmitted by the vectors. Transmission can be seen as a continuum of three overlapping processes: first, acquisition of virions when the vector samples/feeds on a suitable virus-infected plant, second, passage of virions through (and their stable retention in) specific sites within the vector, and third, inoculation of the retained virions into a suitable recipient plant during a subsequent sampling/feeding. Features observed in this continuum have helped frame our understanding of the different modes of virus transmission. Viruses that are transmitted in a non-circulative (NC) manner, unlike those with circulative, propagative (Whitfield et al., in this volume) or circulative, non-propagative (Ghanim et al., in this volume) modes of transmission, need not circulate through, multiply, or invade the salivary glands of their insect vectors. NC transmission is contingent upon virion retention within the stylets or the foreguts of insect vectors [3,4]. Viruses exhibiting NC transmission and are not retained in their vectors beyond minutes to hours have a non-circulative, non-persistent (NCNP) mode of transmission; those that retain in and remain transmissible by their vectors for hours to days exhibit a non-circulative, semi-persistent (NCSP) mode of transmission [5] (and will hereafter be simplified as NCSP viruses). In both cases, virus transmissibility is lost when the vector molts. Here, we review the biology and mechanisms of NCSP transmission. The behaviors and mechanics of vector feeding, described briefly insofar as they are helpful in explaining NCSP transmission, have been examined comprehensively in other reviews [4,6,7].

What about the molecular mechanisms of virus acquisition? While much of it remains unknown, recent investigations of CaMV have yielded novel findings showing that virion acquisition is associated with transmission activation (TA), a phenomenon in which a complex termed the transmission body (TB), containing CaMV encoded proteins (P2 and P3) and virions, disintegrates within an infected plant cell when triggered by mechanical or chemical stresses during stylet probing. This facilitates the re-localization of P2-virions on the cortical microtubules as mixed-networks, the function of which is to promote the distribution of P2 (see section on virus retention) and virions throughout the cell periphery in order to enhance their acquisition by aphid vectors [17••,18• ] (Drucker, in this volume).

Upon ingestion, virion-filled fluid enters the opening at the apex of the maxillary stylets and moves up the maxillary food canal until it reaches the precibarium and cibarium. From here, aided by the compression of the cibarium and closing of the precibarial valve, fluid enters the pharynx and esophagus (Figure 1b). Along this ingestion route, opportunities arise for virions of NCSP viruses to be retained at precise locations within their insect vectors. Two virion retention sites have been identified: the maxillary stylets and a region comprising the cibarium, anterior pharynx and posterior esophagus (generically referred to as the foregut) [19,20••,21,22,23•• ].

Virions of CaMV are retained at the apex of the aphid's maxillary stylets in a common duct (termed the acrostyle) formed by the merger of the food and the salivary canal (Figure 1b and Table 1) [23••,24]. The interaction is specific as it is seen only in the acrostyles of aphid species that transmit CaMV. The virus-driven mechanism underlying CaMV transmission is unequivocal and has been referred to as the ‘helper strategy’ [25] (Table 1). The ‘helper’ aspect of this model refers to the interaction between viral encoded non-capsid proteins P2 and P3, aptly named aphid transmission factors (ATFs); their concurrent association with the interactions between P3 and the coat protein (P4) in the assembled virion, and the physical link that these combined interactions provide to ‘help’ attach the virion to the acrostyle [26]. Retention of CaMV in the acrostyle was determined by several approaches, among which binding assays using dissected maxillary stylets to determine the retention specificity of in vitro expressed P2-GFP (Figure 1b), and of in vitro expressed P2 and purified P3-virion complexes, were insightful [23•• ]. The ‘helper strategy’ first emerged from studies of non-persistent transmission in members of the genus Potyvirus (family Potyviridae). Unlike in CaMV, a solitary viral non-capsid protein, the helper component (HC-Pro), serves as the bridge between the potyvirus virion and the retention site in the vector's maxillary stylets [27]. There is clear evidence that the loss of transmission of CaMV and potyviruses with specific mutations in their ATFs/HC-Pros and coat proteins, as reported in many studies, is due to defective virion retention [23••,28–31]. In the case of Tomato torrado virus (ToTV; genus Torradovirus), which is not known to encode any viral non-capsid proteins similar to HC-Pro or the CaMV ATFs, reverse transcriptase (RT)-PCR detected ToTV sequences in the probosces (Table 1), but not in the heads, of viruliferous whiteflies, suggesting that ToTV may also be retained in the maxillary stylets [32].

Evidence of virion retention in the foregut has also been obtained from the transmission electron microscopy examinations of viruliferous aphid and leafhopper vectors of the Anthirscus yellows virus (AYV)/Parsnip yellow fleck virus (PYFV) complex and Maize chlorotic dwarf virus (MCDV), respectively (Figure 1c–e and Table 1) [19,21,22]. The ‘helper strategy’ has been implicated in the transmission these viruses [36,37]. For the AYV/PYFV complex, the helper function is supplied by AYV, the transmissible member in the complex. As yet, neither the identities of the helper proteins nor concrete evidence of their modes of action in mediating virion retention/transmission has been determined for AYV and MCDV.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Retention in yet to be identified locations
ce:section.ce:para: Interestingly, some members of the whitefly-transmitted Ipomovirus (a genus of Potyviridae) (Table 1) encode an HC-Pro while others do not [38]. It will be worthwhile to determine if ipomoviruses with an HC-Pro, or with other viral encoded proteins that substitute for the HC-Pro, are retained in their vectors’ maxillary stylets; and whether those without an HC-Pro are retained in locations other than the maxillary stylets (such as the foregut). The leafhopper-transmitted Rice tungro spherical virus (RTSV)/Rice tungro bacilliform virus (RTBV) complex [39] as well as several other aphid-transmitted, whitefly-transmitted, leafhopper-transmitted, mealybug-transmitted, and soft scale-transmitted viruses are other examples of NCSP viruses for which information on virion retention sites and mechanisms are largely unavailable (Table 1). For RTSV/RTBV, a helper dependent transmission strategy has been shown, with the helper function being provided by RTSV, the transmissible member of the complex. However, the identity of the helper protein(s) and the mechanisms underlying its/their function are unknown.

The mechanics of NCSP virus inoculation have been inferred from EPG waveforms and/or other features associated with vector (mostly aphid and whitefly) feeding, including the transmission of stylet-borne and foregut-borne viruses [16•,20••,40–43]. Together, the information has helped strengthen two hypotheses (ingestion–salivation and ingestion–egestion) explaining the mechanical actions that mediate virion inoculation. Because salivation and ingestion (occurring in that order) take place during both sampling and phloem-feeding [42,44,45], the ingestion–salivation hypothesis provides a logical explanation for how previously ingested virions, now retained at the tip of the maxillary stylets (at the point of convergence with the salivary canal; Figure 1b), are released and inoculated when contacted by the flow of watery saliva from the salivary canal. In aphids, watery saliva secreted during phloem-feeding is purportedly swept up the food canal with the ingested sap [4]. Thus, it is conceivable that the mixture of saliva and sap may also contact virions that are retained past the point of maxillary stylets/salivary canal convergence and, possibly, as far up as in the foregut. Therefore, ingestion–salivation appears relevant to the inoculation of both stylet-borne and foregut-borne viruses. The contents of aphid saliva have been studied and found to contain proteins implicated in modulating plant defense responses [46–50]. However, whether or not and how aphid saliva is involved in triggering virion inoculation is unknown. The role, if any, of saliva in mediating virion inoculation by other hemipteran vectors has also not been demonstrated.

The ingestion–egestion hypothesis proposes that retained virions are released and inoculated into the plant during egestion (a mechanical function aided by reversing fluid flow in the cibarium [Figure 1b]) [40]. On the basis of this model, virions of stylet-borne and foregut-borne viruses located in the path of the reversed fluid flow can both be egested. If virion inoculation is a purely mechanical event mediated only by egestion, then it is imperative that the force generated by fluid flow must be sufficient to dislodge and expel the retained virions. Unfortunately, technology has yet to develop the capability to determine the dynamics of fluid flow inside the maxillary stylets or foregut. On the basis of existing evidence, it is more than likely that the inoculation of both foregut-borne and stylet-borne viruses may be mediated by a combination of salivation and egestion. In one probable scenario, a mixture of saliva and sap, along with prevailing dietary conditions (Ng, unpublished data), may work cooperatively to facilitate the release of virions, while egestion takes place at the same time or afterwards to complete the inoculation process.

Clearly, the interactions involved in virion release during the inoculation phase are unknown for NCSP viruses. Future investigations are needed to address the fundamental mechanisms underlying this process; the question of what factors (sap and saliva component as well as dietary conditions) are involved in virion inoculation will be particularly pertinent.

An unhindered continuum of processes (virion acquisition, retention and inoculation) contributing to successful NCSP transmission requires the concerted actions of all three participants—the virus, the vector, and the plant. Transmission can be affected by suboptimal virion acquisition due to a virion distribution scheme (in the plant) that is not in-sync with vector feeding behavior. The discovery of a specialized mechanism, TA, seen in the transmission of CaMV, a tissue generalist, indicates how changes in virion distribution within an infected cell play a role in optimizing virion acquisition. In this regard, it will be interesting for future studies to determine if the transmission of phloem-restricted NCSP viruses also involves TA or mechanisms that are similar to it.

Loss of virus transmission may arise from defective virion retention. So far, CaMV and LIYV are the only NCSP viruses for which definitive retention sites and mechanisms have been revealed through the use of transmission defective mutants. Similar studies will be needed to determine the retention sites and mechanisms of other NCSP viruses. For LIYV and other criniviruses, a structure-based approach to studying the CPm's function in virion retention will further contribute to a mechanistic view of the molecular bases involved in this process.

Another consideration in understanding virion retention mechanisms is the identities of the receptors in the maxillary stylets and foregut to which stylet-borne and foregut-borne viruses, respectively, are attached. Because the surfaces of the foregut and maxillary stylets are covered with cuticle consisting of a chitinous intima embedded in a protein matrix [24,51], it is conceivable that cuticular proteins may function as receptors. This hypothesis is, in part, supported by data from Uzest et al. [23•• ], demonstrating that treatment of dissected maxillary stylets of aphid vectors with specific proteases (with or without chitinase treatment) abolished CaMV P2 binding (Figure 1b). The identity of this and other receptors of NCSP viruses and proof of their role in virion retention await future discovery. In the case of LIYV and LCV, because both viruses are retained and transmitted specifically by B. tabaci NW, this suggests that the same receptors in the foregut of B. tabaci NW may accommodate the retention of LIYV and LCV. Alternatively, there may be different receptors in the foregut of B. tabaci NW that interact independently with both viruses. Co-localization studies of LIYV and LCV within B. tabaci NW will help resolve this in the near future.

Understanding the behavioral, cellular and molecular bases underlying the tripartite relationship among NCSP virus, vector and plant holds the potential for new opportunities aimed at breaking the transmission continuum, such as disrupting virion acquisition and interfering with virion retention or release.

Papers of particular interest, published within the period of review, have been highlighted as:
• of special interest
•• of outstanding interest

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We apologize to the colleagues whose work was not included in this review due to space limitation. We are grateful to Greg Walker for helpful discussions. Work performed in our laboratory is supported by grants from the National Science Foundation and the United States Department of Agriculture.

ce:note.ce:simple-para: The authors show that acquisition and inoculation of non-persistently transmitted viruses are identifiable by specific EPG waveforms associated with brief, distinct intracellular punctures made by aphids.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: A virus responds instantly to the presence of the vector on the host and forms transmission morphs
Elife

ce:note.ce:simple-para: The authors show that TA of CaMV involves the interaction among virions, viral encoded proteins (P2 and P3) that form a specialized TB within infected plant cells, the plant cell microtubule network, and the aphid vector.

Plant J

ce:note.ce:simple-para: The authors show that microtubules are required for the formation of electron-lucent inclusion bodies (also called transmission bodies in subsequent work), consisting of the CaMV encoded proteins P2 and P3.
